grammar_notes: First person singular of 'ser' - used for identity profession nationality
cultural_note: Often used to introduce yourself: 'Sou o João' (I'm João)
tip: No article needed with professions: 'Sou médico' not 'Sou um médico'

grammar_notes: Informal 2nd person - accent distinguishes from archaic 'es'
cultural_note: Used with 'tu' - informal settings like friends and family
tip: Notice the acute accent (é) - indicates stressed syllable

grammar_notes: Used with ele/ela/você - most common form in daily conversation
cultural_note: This form covers he/she AND formal you (você)
tip: This single form works for he she it and formal you!

cultural_note: In casual speech 'A gente é' (singular) often used instead of 'Nós somos'
tip: Remember: nós somos BUT a gente é

grammar_notes: Third person plural - used with eles/elas/vocês
cultural_note: Most versatile plural form - covers multiple people in any context

grammar_notes: Infinitive form - use for permanent states identity origin characteristics
cultural_note: SER vs ESTAR: SER = permanent / ESTAR = temporary
example2_en: I want to be a doctor.
